questions.text: A patient on multidrug therapy for leprosy for the past 6 months presented with fever and onset of new tender subcutaneous nodules over forearms and elbows. On investigation, tumour necrosis factor-alpha levels were raised. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the onset of new subcutaneous nodules along with the prevalence of systemic symptoms in a patient with leprosy is suggestive of Type 2 lepra reaction or erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL).

Type 2 leprosy reaction is seen in multibacillary leprosy (lepromatous leprosy and borderline lepromatous leprosy). It is seen as a development of new, erythematous and tender, subcutaneous, and dermal nodules that are widely distributed over the face and extremities.

It is unrelated to multidrug therapy (MDT) and is commonly associated with systemic symptoms such as fever, myalgia, arthralgia, and orchitis. Raised tumor necrosis factor-alpha is often seen.

The first-line treatment is oral corticosteroids. Other drugs used in treatment are clofazimine (steroid-dependent ENL) and thalidomide (most effective but not commonly used due to adverse side effects)

Other options: 

Option A: Type 1 leprosy reaction is seen in borderline leprosy and frequently presents with changes like erythema, tenderness, and edema in existing leprosy lesions. There may be neuritis with loss of sensory and motor functions. Constitutional symptoms are not usually seen.

Option B: Tuberculoid leprosy presents with solitary lesions in form of dry, insensitive, hairless macule or plaque with a hypopigmented center.

Option D: Lepromatous leprosy presents as macules that may be faintly hypopigmented or erythematous with vague edges and shiny surfaces. Hair growth and sensation are not initially impaired over the lesions.

Tuberculoid leprosy and lepromatous leprosy are types of leprosy and not lepra reactions. Lepra reactions generally occur only after initiation of multidrug therapy. They are abrupt in onset, unlike leprosy itself where changes develop slowly.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient presented with erythematous papules encircled by a middle pale zone and a peripheral erythematous ring. These lesions were distributed bilaterally over the soles and palms. She has a history of mild fever 10 days ago for which she took non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The lesion mentioned above with erythematous papules encircled by a middle pale zone and a peripheral erythematous ring describes characteristic target lesions seen in erythema multiforme.

Erythema multiforme is a self-limiting cytotoxic dermatitis as a result of cell-mediated hypersensitivity to infections or drugs. Some triggers include HSV-1(most common), drugs like NSAIDs, and conditions like lupus erythematosus and leukemias.

Target lesions are less than 3 cm in diameter and have 3 zones-

  • The central zone is a dusky area with papule/vesicle/bullae
  • The intermediate zone is a pale oedematous zone
  • The peripheral zone shows the rim of erythema (around the lesion)

Treatment of erythema multiforme includes treatment of underlying cause and steroids.

Other conditions in which target lesions are seen are Lyme's disease (called erythema migrans) and paraneoplastic pemphigus.

The following image depicts target lesions: 

Other options: 

Option A - Irritant contact dermatitis occurs due to the physical or toxic effects of environmental exposures. It has a wide range of features from stinging and burning to persistent dryness, capping, or acute caustic burn. The following image shows irritant contact dermatitis of the hand: 

Option C - Fixed drug reaction is an adverse reaction to a drug characterized by recurrent lesions that are well-defined present in the same location every time the drug is taken. The lesions are generally well-defined, round, oval, erythematous, or edematous that become violaceous or vesicular. 

Option D - Steven Johnson's syndrome is a mucocutaneous reaction to drugs that is characterized by blistering and epithelial sloughing. Toxic epidermal necrolysis is a severe version of this condition. 

Related Pearl: Skin rashes (Erythemas)

Erythema marginatum is an evanescent, non-pruritic rash over the trunk and extremities seen in rheumatic fever.

 

Erythema nodosum is an acute, nodular, erythematous, painful eruption, occurring probably due to a delayed hypersensitivity reaction to a variety of antigens. Lesions are usually seen over the extensor aspects of the legs. Its causes include infections (tuberculosis), autoimmune (IBD and sarcoidosis), idiopathic.

 

Erythema migrans has a bull's-eye appearance (central erythema and necrosis) and is seen in Lyme disease.

 

Erythema multiforme lesions usually have a target appearance; it is mediated by the deposition of immune complexes in the superficial microvasculature of the skin and oral mucosal membrane. It is usually triggered by certain infections (herpes simplex virus) and drugs.

questions.text: A child presented with patchy hair loss. On examination, black dots over the scalp and patchy baldness without inflammation are seen. Wood's lamp examination shows no fluorescence. Which of the following is not associated with the likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
The history and findings of black dots (swollen, broken hair shafts) smooth patchy hair loss without inflammation suggest a likely diagnosis of black dot tinea capitis. Ectothrix infection is not associated and it is a type of endothrix infection.

Tinea capitis refers to ringworm of the scalp in which there is an invasion of the hair shafts by a dermatophyte fungus.

The endothrix variant of Tinea capitis is commonly caused by T. tonsurans. It presents as non-inflammatory smooth patchy alopecia with minimal scaling of the scalp. There is a classical formation of black dots due to hair that has broken off close to the scalp surface but this sign is not specific to this disease. 

Other clinical variants of tinea capitis are:

  • Ectothrix variant of tinea capitis commonly occurs due to small‐spored M. audouiniia. It is a mild inflammatory type in which single or multiple patches of hair loss with characteristic fine scaling are seen.
  • Kerion is a severe inflammatory type commonly caused due to T.mentagarophytes. It presents as an inflammatory mass with thick crusting and matting of hair with pus and sinus formation. Lymphadenopathy is often seen in patients with kerion.
  • Favus is caused by T. schoenleinii. It is characterized by the presence of yellowish, cup‐shaped crusts known as scutula that develop around hair follicles. 

Wood's lamp examination is used to check for fluorescence over the infected areas. The Wood's lamp examination in tinea capitis can show the following findings:

  • M. audouinii will give a green to a yellow-green color.
  • T. schoenleinii may show a greenish grey color
  • T. tonsurans usually do not show fluorescence.

Tinea capitis is treated with oral therapy of griesofulvin, itraconazole, or terbinafine.

questions.text: A patient with plaque psoriasis presents with lesions involving the axillary, inframammary, and inguinal creases. On examination, these lesions are well-demarcated, smooth, moist, and erythematous, with no scaling.  Which of the following types could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with lesions with minimal scaling and moist, smooth surfaces involving flexural areas (the axillary, inframammary, and inguinal creases) in a patient with plaque psoriasis elsewhere suggests a likely diagnosis of inverse psoriasis.

Inverse psoriasis (also called flexural psoriasis or intertriginous psoriasis) refers to psoriasis of the flexural areas such as the inguinal creases, axillae, inframammary, and other body folds. Unlike characteristic lesions of psoriasis, these plaques are thin, with minimal or no scaling. The surface is glazed with fissuring.

Inverse psoriasis may manifest as new lesions occurring on the body or the Koebner phenomenon on top of existing intertriginous dermatoses, or it may be present along with classical plaque psoriasis. It typically involves the diaper area in infants, referred to as napkin psoriasis. It may also affect older, obese patients. An image of inverse psoriasis is shown below:


Psoriasis is characterized by erythematous plaques covered with silver scales. It generally affects the extensor surfaces. The peak occurrence is between 16 to 22 years and between 57 to 62 years.

Plaque psoriasis is the most common type of psoriasis. It presents with pruritis and a papulosquamous rash. Lesions can be described as red, scaly, and a well-defined demarcation from the normal skin. The scales often appear white and silvery. The lesions may be encircled by a clear peripheral zone which is called the Woronoff ring. They are seen in the scalp, trunk, and extensor surfaces of the limbs.

Based on morphology, psoriasis is classified into the following clinical variants:

Option B: Guttate psoriasis  - Sudden onset of small lesions on the trunk and proximal limbs, in children. It usually occurs weeks after streptococcal pharyngitis. It is shown in the image below.


Option C: Erythrodermic psoriasis is a severe, rare form of psoriasis marked by generalized erythema covering over 75% of the body surface and accompanied by diffuse scaling. It can lead to severe illness with fever and dehydration. The pathogenesis involves a complex interaction between genetic, environmental, and immune system factors, similar to other psoriasis types. Clinically, it presents with widespread red, scaly skin, often with pustules, and may include systemic symptoms such as fever and dehydration. Image is shown below:


Option D: Seborrhoeic psoriasis or sebopsoriasis presents as thin, demarcated erythema with scales. It is typically seen in areas that are involved in seborrhoeic dermatitis- paranasal areas, external ears, medial eyebrows, hairline, presternal, and interscapular chest wall.

Pustular psoriasis- Appearance of macroscopic pustules within lesions.
Unstable psoriasis (active psoriasis, eruptive inflammatory psoriasis) - Characterized by actively enlarging erythematous plaques, with the development of new smaller plaques

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old female patient with multiple painful blisters on the forearms, trunk, and mouth is suspected to have pemphigus vulgaris. Which of the following are helpful in the diagnosis of this condition?
  1. Diascopy
  2. KOH mount microscopy
  3. Direct immunofluorescence
  4. Tzanck smear
  5. Patch testing
questions.solution:
Direct immunofluorescence and Tzanck smear (3 and 4) are helpful in the diagnosis of pemphigus vulgaris. 

The diagnostic and most accurate investigation for pemphigus vulgaris is direct immunofluorescence microscopy which shows a characteristic fishnet appearance due to intraepidermal intercellular deposition of IgG and C3.

Tzanck smear is done by opening an intact blister and scraping material from the base of the ulcer formed. It is then smeared onto a microscopic slide, air-dried, and stained with Giemsa stain. The presence of acantholytic cells in cytology is indicative of pemphigus vulgaris, but is not specific.

Pemphigus is a group of immunobullous disorders that are characterized by the presence of antibodies against desmosomal adhesion proteins, desmoglein 1 and desmoglein 3.

Clinically, it presents with multiple flaccid bullae over oral mucosa. The disease then progresses to involve the scalp, face, neck, upper chest, and back. The blisters are filled with clear fluid which may become turbid and rupture to form erosions. The Nikolsky sign is positive at this stage. It refers to the separation of the normal‐looking epidermis from the dermis, producing an erosion when firm sliding pressure is applied.

Histopathology shows suprabasal clefts and blisters, acantholysis and a row of tombstone appearance.

Topical steroids, oral prednisolone, and oral azathioprine are used for the treatment depending on the severity of the disease.

The image below shows the presence of acantholytic cells on the Tzanck smear seen in pemphigus -

 

The image below shows the characteristic fish net appearance seen in pemphigus on DIF-

Other statements:

Statement 1- Diascopy is a method of assessing superficial erythema, where a glass slide is pressed against the skin. Indications include telangiectasia, petechiae and purpura, and granulomatous nodules like sarcoidosis and lupus vulgaris.

Statement 2- KOH mount microscopy permits visualization of the hyphae and spores of dermatophytes or other fungal infections.

Statement 5- Patch testing is a test of cell-mediated immunity, to determine whether a patient has a contact sensitivity to a given allergen.

Related Pearl: Tzanck Smear in Dermatology

The Tzanck smear, introduced by the Frenchman Tzanck, is a simple to perform, inexpensive bed side cytological test that aids in the diagnosis of vesicular, pustular and bullous diseases, in particular herpes.

The sensitivity of the Tzanck smear exceeds 80%, and the specificity 90% when the investigators are experienced.

Preparation of Tzanck smear:

  • Viral infections and Blistering disorders - fresh vesicle or intact blister is de-roofed and base is scraped 
  • Suspected tumors - any crust should be removed from ulcerated tumors, and non-ulcerated tumors should be incised with a sharp, pointed scalpel and sample is then obtained with either a blunt scalpel or a small curette
  • The smear should preferably be fixed immediately using Formol-Zenker solution since significant artifacts can result from drying.
  • Tzanck smear can be stained by a variety of methods, most commonly by Giemsa stain. Other stains used are hematoxylin and eosin, Wright, methylene blue, Papanicolaou and toluidine blue. 

Results in Tzanck Smear:

A typical Tzanck cell is a large round keratinocyte with a hypertrophic nucleus, hazy or absent nucleoli, and abundant basophilic cytoplasm. The basophilic staining is deeper peripherally on the cell membrane ("mourning edged" cells) due to the cytoplasm's tendency to get condensed at the periphery, leading to a perinuclear halo.

questions.text: A dermatology call is made for a patient with multiple soft tissue swellings over the skin and oral cavity. She was admitted for heart failure due to the presence of bilateral atrial myxomas. On examination,  multiple lentigines were distributed over the body and the presence of a blue nevus on the lips was seen. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of a patient with lentigines, atrial myxomas, mucocutaneous myxomas, and blue naevi suggests a diagnosis of LAMB syndrome. It is a part of the Carney complex.

Carney complex or myxoma syndrome is a group of disorders due to an autosomal dominant mutation in the gene encoding a subunit of protein kinase A. It presents as hyperpigmented cutaneous lesions associated with cutaneous, subcutaneous, or internal myxoma and associated endocrinopathy (of one or more of the adrenal cortex, thyroid, gonad, and pituitary gland)

Carney's complex includes: 

LAMB syndrome is lentigines (hypermelanotic patches on the skin that do not disappear on exposure to UV rays), atrial myxomas, mucocutaneous myxomas, and blue naevi.

NAME syndrome is naevi, atrial myxomas, myxoid neurofibromas, and ephelides (freckles).

Other Options:

Option A: Xeroderma pigmentosum is an autosomal recessive disease that presents as early age photosensitivity with myriads of lentigines distributed in sun-exposed areas. The patients are at a higher risk of developing skin cancers throughout their life.

Option C: Tuberous sclerosis complex presents as cutaneous angiokeratomas, epilepsy, internal hamartomatous tumours, and learning difficulties.

Option D: Nodular basal cell carcinoma presents as surface telangiectasia over a flesh‐coloured mass or the tumour may be pink or red in colour

Related Pearl: Carney's complex, triad, and diad

Carney complex includes:

  • Myxomas - cardiac, skin, and/or breast
  • Lentigines and/or pigmented nevi
  • Endocrine overactivity - primary nodular adrenal cortical disease, testicular tumors, and/or pituitary adenomas with gigantism or acromegaly

 Carney's triad includes:

  • Gastrointestinal stromal tumor
  • Pulmonary chondroma
  • Extraadrenal paraganglioma

Carney-Stratakis syndrome also called Carney's diad includes:

  • GIST
  • Paraganglioma

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient visits the Dermatology OPD with complaints of severe pruritis and rash over his left leg. On examination, the resident notices multiple maculopapular lesions with a central hemorrhagic punctum distributed in a breakfast-lunch-dinner pattern over the anterior aspect of the left leg. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes the presence of maculopapular lesions with central hemorrhagic punctum distributed in a breakfast-lunch-dinner pattern a characteristic lesions of bed bug infestation.

Bed bug infestation is commonly caused by Cimex lectularius. This bug is confined to tropical and subtropical areas like India, Malaysia and Central Africa. The passive transmission of bed bugs is usually through means of clothing. Active dissemination can occur through ventilation ducts. Bed bugs usually feed at night and fear light and avoid glossy surfaces. Under ideal circumstances, bed bugs can survive starvation for a year.

Beg bug bites clinically present as pruritic maculopapular lesions centred by the bite seen as haemorrhagic punctum overexposed areas of the body. The initial bite is usually not felt because of the anaesthetic in the saliva of the bug. The saliva also contains an anticoagulant. Clinical manifestations are usually due to the allergic reaction to the saliva of the bug and are commonly seen 10 days after the bite. The lesions classically disappear when the sleeping place is changed and the person sharing a bed with the patient might have similar symptoms.

The diagnosis is usually clinical. The distribution of lesions shows a characteristic breakfast-lunch-dinner pattern. In breakfast -unch-dinner pattern, lesions are grouped on a line or a curve and this pattern is not can be found in other arthropod infestations.  

Management includes:

Patient education about washing clothing and linen items in order to kill all life stages of Cimex lectularius. It is recommended to avoid usage of second-hand bedding in order to prevent getting infected.

Topical steroids and systemic antihistamines are used to relieve symptoms of pruritis

Other options:

Option B Scabies is an ectoparasitic infestation caused in humans by the Sarcoptes scabiei var. hominins. The characteristic symptoms of a scabies infection include intense itching and superficial burrows. Burrows present as slightly raised brownish tortuous lesions. In most people, the trails of the burrowing mites are linear in the skin. 

The image below shows a photo of a scabies burrow. The large scaly patch at the left is due to scratching. At the upper right, the scabies mite can be seen at the end of the burrow.

Option C Larva currens is the urticarial wheal and flare produced by migrating subcutaneous larvae of Strongyloides spp. These lesions are commonly present in the anus and buttocks region. 

The image below shows larva currens:

Option D Cutaneous larva migrans. They present as pruritic erythematous papules at the site of penetration of the hookworms with an erythematous serpiginous larva track.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is referred to a dermatologist with a history of the development of multiple large bullae and crusting around the nose and mouth. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describing large bullae and crusting of lesions in a young child is suggestive of a diagnosis of bullous impetigo.

Impetigo is a contagious superficial pyogenic infection of the skin. It is mainly caused by Staphylococcal infections and less commonly by Streptococcal infections. It is frequently seen in preschool and young age children. Poor hygiene, overcrowding, and existing skin diseases (especially scabies and eczema) predispose to a higher occurrence of impetigo.

The site is commonly involved in the skin around the nose and the mouth. It has two types.

  • Bullous impetigo presents as large bullae that progressively increase in size (1-2 cm in diameter) and do not rupture easily.
  • Non-bullous impetigo presents as thin-walled vesicles with an erythematous base.

The diagnosis is mainly clinical but skin scrapings from affected skin can be obtained for microbiological confirmation.

Bullous impetigo is treated with systemic antibiotics. In addition to that, the management of impetigo involves washing the skin, removing crusts, and applying topical antibiotics. 

The image below shows a picture of bullous impetigo with the presence of large bullae and crusting over ruptured lesions:

This is an image of an impetigo around the mouth showing the honey-colored crusts:

Other options:

Option A: Bullous pemphigoid presents mainly in elderly people. It starts with urticated and erythematous lesions, which may be pruritic. This is followed by the formation of tense blisters on normal or erythematous skin. Histopathology shows subepidermal splitting, and autoantibodies are seen against BP180 and BP230.

Option C: Pemphigus vulgaris presents with mucosal erosions, usually in the oral mucosa. These may precede cutaneous lesions or be the only manifestation. Cutaneous lesions are seen as flaccid blisters filled with clear fluid, mainly on the scalp, neck, face, and upper trunk. These may rupture and become painful erosions.

Option D: Herpes labialis presents as itching or burning followed by the formation of small closely grouped vesicles on an inflamed base, usually around the mouth.

Related Pearl: Skin and soft tissue lesions caused by Staphylococcus

Staphylococcus causes a variety of skin and soft tissue infections. These include:

a. Furuncle/boil- Infection of the hair follicle.

The given image shows a furuncle:

 

b. Carbuncle: A cluster of several furuncles:

The given image shows a carbuncle:

 

c. Bullous impetigo: Results in large blisters called bullae, usually seen in areas with skin folds such as armpits, groin, buttocks, etc.

The given image shows ruptured bullous impetigo:

 

d. Cellulitis: It is a rapidly spreading infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue, usually associated with wounds, incisions, burns, etc.

The given image shows cellulitis following an abrasion. The red streaks indicate the involvement of the lymphatics:

 

e. Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome: Caused by exfoliating toxin that causes peeling of the skin.

The given image shows SSSS:

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient presented with purplish, itchy, flat-topped lesions on his shins for the past 3 months. The patient also gives a history of chewing tobacco for 20 years. She occasionally drinks alcohol and smokes. On examination, the lesions are seen as in the image below. Which of the following is the first line of management?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and characteristic lesions showing fine white lacework in buccal mucosa called Wickham's striae shown in the image are diagnostic of lichen planus. The first line of management is potent topical corticosteroids like clobetasol propionate ointment 0.05%.

Lichen planus is a type of lichenoid disorder affecting the papillary dermis. It is a T-cell mediated autoimmune disease against the basal keratinocytes. Various factors that can precipitate the disease are:

  • Viruses like Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C, Human herpesviruses (HHV-6, HHV-8), Varicella zoster
  • Betel quid which contains areca nut and tobacco leaf
  • Environmental factors like:
    • Drugs like antimicrobials, antihypertensives, antimalarials, antidepressants, anticonvulsants
    • Radiotherapy
    • Anxiety, depression, stress

It is recommended to avoid spicy and acidic foods, as well as avoid tobacco and alcohol.

The most common presentation of lichen planus is a well-defined area of purple-colored, itchy, flat-topped papules. This description is known as the characteristic "6 Ps" of lichen planus: planar (flat-topped), purple, polygonal, pruritic, papules, and plaques.

White streaks forming a lacework in buccal mucosa are characteristic features and are known as Wickham’s striae.

 

Investigations include:

  • Histology: Most useful investigation to confirm the diagnosis. Basal epidermal cell degeneration/destruction by dermal CD8+ T lymphocytes is characteristically seen in lichen planus. Other findings are:
    • Hyperkeratosis
    • The degeneration leads to the formation of spaces in the epidermis known as Max-Joseph spaces.
    • Saw-toothed appearance of the Rete ridges
    • Band-like lymphocytic infiltrate is present at the dermo-epidermal junction. 

 

 

Other Options:

Options A, and C: Ciclosporin, and methotrexate are used in third-line management and not first-line management of the disease.

Option D: Oral corticosteroids are used in the second-line management of the disease.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents with lesions as seen in the image below. She gives a history of having primary pulmonary tuberculosis in early childhood. She also gives a history of getting a tattoo over the lateral aspect of her neck 6 months ago. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the characteristic reddish-brown nodules, plaques, and ulcers with variable scarring and a serpiginous edge are suggestive of lupus vulgaris. Lupus vulgaris is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis that occurs in previously sensitized individuals. 

Lupus vulgaris originates from an underlying focus of tuberculosis, typically in a bone, joint, or lymph node, or maybe from the hematogenous and lymphatic spread. It can also occur over a primary site of inoculation such as the site of scrofuloderma scar, BCG vaccine, and after a tattoo. 

It presents as a slowly enlarging plaque with an elevated border and central atrophy. The edges of the lesion are often serpiginous in shape and heal with scarring. 

In India, the buttocks and trunk are more frequently involved. In Europe, 80% of the lesions are present on the head, neck, and face. The diascopy of lesions reveals diagnostic apple jelly nodules.

Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) has been successfully used to confirm the diagnosis. 

Standard multidrug therapy for tuberculosis is used for the treatment. Isoniazid monotherapy is not given anymore due to the emergence of isoniazid-resistant Mycobacterium tuberculosis strains.

The image given below shows lupus vulgaris.

Other options:

Option A: Scrofuloderma results from the direct invasion of the tubercle bacillus into the skin from an underlying contiguous tuberculous focus. It commonly occurs in children. It begins as bluish-red subcutaneous swellings, which ulcerate to form discharging sinuses.

The image given below shows scrofuloderma.

Option C: Lichen scrofulosorum is a type of tuberculid. It is seen in children with active tuberculosis. They appear as closely grouped lichenoid papules. They are mainly seen on the abdomen, chest, back, and proximal limbs.

The image given below shows lichen scrofulosorum.

Option D: Erythema induratum of Bazin is the most commonly reported tuberculid. Patients present with crops of small, tender, and painful erythematous or dusky nodules or plaques on the calves, which may ulcerate. Most patients will have a positive tuberculin test and respond well to antituberculous therapy.

The image given below shows erythema induratum.

questions.text:
A 20-year old female patient presented with painless lesions on the vulva as shown in the image below. Which of the following organisms is implicated in the etiology of the likely diagnosis?

HPV- Human papilloma virus
questions.solution:
The image showing multiple warty growths on the vulva suggests a likely diagnosis of condyloma acuminata which is caused by HPV 6 or HPV 11.

Condyloma acuminata is a genital infection caused by the human papillomavirus(HPV) commonly HPV‐6 and HPV‐11. HPV‐1 and HPV‐2 may also occur in genital warts. Transmission of HPV commonly occurs sexually or through the genital lesions of the mother during delivery.

The lesions present as soft, pink, fleshy, anogenital warts. These growths may be pedunculated discrete or verrucous that coalesce to form large cauliflower-like growths. It commonly occurs on the glans, corona, and frenulum in men and the posterior fourchette in women. 

Diagnosis is done by HPV DNA PCR (polymerase chain reaction). The first-line drugs used in the treatment are podophyllin and imiquimod. Cryotherapy and surgical management can be tried as second-line management. Interferon therapy can be used for severe extensive warts.

The available vaccines that protect against this disease are Gardasil and Gardasil-9. Gardasil protects against HPV types 6, 11, 16, and 18. Gardasil-9 is a nonavalent vaccine and protects against types 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58 in addition to the types covered by Gardasil.

The use of condoms, limiting the number of sex partners and abstaining from sexual activity can lower the chances of acquiring and transmitting HPV infection.

questions.text: A female patient who recently began playing the violin presents with acne on the neck. She plays for several hours a day. On examination, the lesions are seen where the violin comes in contact with the skin. Which type of acne is this?
questions.solution:
This patient with new-onset acne after beginning playing the violin is likely to have acne mechanica. 

The term acne mechanica describes acneform lesions that occur at the site of repeated mechanical trauma and/or frictional obstruction of the pilosebaceous outlet. Examples include mechanical pressure from high‐necked jerseys, shoulder pads, seat backs in trucks, or adhesive plasters causing acneform folliculitis.

Fiddler's neck is a type of acne mechanica seen in violinists with the presence of multiple plaques and comedones over the neck. This is caused due to repeated mechanical trauma caused to the neck of the skin while holding a violin.

Other Options:

Option B: Acne vulgaris is a form of acne in which the lesions present as comedones, pustules and/or nodules of varying degrees of inflammation and depth. Lesions seen specifically at sites of repeated mechanical trauma suggest acne mechanica rather than acne vulgaris.

Option C: Acne conglobata is a rare and severe form of acne that presents with multiple extensive inflammatory papules, tender nodules, and abscesses that coalesce to form draining sinus tracts. 

Option D: Acne fulminans is a rare and severe destructive form of acne seen primarily in adolescent males. It presents with hemorrhagic ulcerations and constitutional symptoms like fever and arthralgia.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with changes over the skin of the nose as seen in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image above shows an exophytic, pink, lobulated mass over the nose with superficial vascular dilation suggesting a diagnosis of phymatous rosacea or rhinophyma.

Acne rosacea is a type of acne that is present in white, middle-aged patients. It is characterized by facial erythema.

The various subtypes of acne rosacea-

  • Erythematotelangiectatic rosacea is the stage where there are multiple telangiectasias and facial erythema present. Facial vascular hyperreactivity is often seen.
  • Papulopustular rosacea is characterized by small dome-shaped papules with tiny areas of pustulation and perilesional erythema. 
  • Phymatous rosacea is characterized by thickened skin and prominent follicular openings. Rhinophyma is the commonest type of phymatous rosacea. There is marked nasal distortion with an increase in size and a bulbous tip.
  • Ocular rosacea presents with eye involvement. Patients have dryness, slight itching, and grittiness early in the disease.

The diagnosis is clinical. General guidelines in the management of acne rosacea:

  • Use sunscreens with both UVA and UVB protection.
  • Use soap‐free, pH‐balanced detergents and lukewarm water to wash the face.
  • Avoid astringents, abrasive exfoliators, and procedures such as dermabrasion.
  • Avoid environments that may overheat and/or dry the skin

Treatment for various subtypes of acne rosacea:

Erythema in erythematotelangiectatic rosacea is treated with topical α‐receptor agonists such as brimonidine or oxymetazoline.

In papulopustular rosacea, active inflammatory lesions are treated using topical agents such as metronidazole 0.75% gel, azelaic acid 15% gel, and sulfur 5% preparations.

Phytomatous rosacea is treated by the nasal application of a skin‐peeling agent for treating large occluded follicles and oily skin. Perinasal telangiectatic vessels are ablated with electrocautery or laser. Isotretinoin therapy can be considered if the condition is progressive.

Ocular rosacea is managed by maintaining daily lid hygiene, using warm compresses to aid the removal of secretions, and lubricating eye drops.

Various layers of the epidermis from superficial to deep are as follows:

  • Stratum spinosum or prickle cell layer is formed by the enlargement of epibasal keratinocytes

The term Malpighian layer encompasses both stratum spinosum and stratum basale.

questions.text: A child is brought to the dermatology outpatient department with the following skin findings. On complete physical examination, no other abnormalities were found. Hearing was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image showing a V-shaped congenital hypomelanotic patch in the absence of any other pathological clinical signs suggests a diagnosis of piebaldism.

Piebaldism is a congenital disorder caused by a dominant mutation in the KIT gene, leading to impaired migration of melanocytes. Clinically, it presents an isolated hypopigmented patch at birth. The biopsy specimen from the lesion shows absent melanocytes or large atypical melanocytes.

It affects the population and affects both sexes equally. The most common clinical presentation is the presence of a V-shaped hypomelanotic patch on the forehead at birth.

Diagnosis is mainly clinical. Treatment is conservative and includes sun protection at the site of the hypomelanotic patch. Epidermal or skin grafting can be tried for aesthetic purposes of treatment.

Piebaldism can be distinguished from vitiligo because of the neonatal presence of white patches.

Option B: Skin findings suggestive of piebaldism, along with the presence of sensorineural deafness, point toward Waardenburg syndrome.

Option C: Oculocutaneous albinism (OCA) is a rare autosomal recessive disorder. It is characterized by generalized depigmentation of the skin, hair, and eye due to a deficiency in melanin biosynthesis.

Option D: Chédiak–Higashi syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder. It is characterized by hypopigmentation of the skin and eye (fair skin, translucent iris), immunodeficiency, and possibly neurological symptoms. It is suspected in patients with features of oculocutaneous albinism combined with severe pyogenic infections.

questions.text:

  2. Nail pitting
  3. Ridging
  4. Onycholysis with subungual keratosis
questions.solution:
The correct option matching the nail changes in psoriasis with the corresponding images is 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, and 4-B.

Any part of the nail unit may be affected. This includes the nail bed, nail matrix, and hyponychium.

Nail matrix disease presents with pits, ridges, and grooves in the nail plate. Pitting is the most frequent change seen in fingernails. 

Nail bed disease is seen as subungual ‘oil drops.’ It is highly specific for psoriasis. Other changes involving the nail bed include subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

questions.text: A 27-year-old lady who is a known diabetic with a body mass index of 32 presents to you with skin lesions as shown in the image below. She has no other complaints. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in an obese woman with diabetes and the image showing dark velvety patches present in the axilla is acanthosis nigricans. 

Acanthosis nigricans (AN) is a skin condition characterized by symmetrical darkening of the skin of intertriginous areas, mainly the axillae, groins, submammary folds, and neck. Obesity and insulin resistance are the most common associations with AN. Other conditions associated with AN are:

  • Acromegaly and gigantism
  • Diabetes
  • Drug-induced- nicotinic acid, and exogenous estrogens, including oral contraceptives.
  • Polycystic ovary syndrome
  • Gastrointestinal malignancy

Familial AN is rare and transmitted as an autosomal dominant trait.

Histology shows hyperkeratosis and finger‐like upward projections of der­mal papillae called papillomatosis. Pigmentation is due to hyperkeratosis and there is no increase in melanocyte numbers or in melanin production. 

Clinically, the skin is darkened and thickened with a vel­vety texture.

Treatment of the underlying condition is the mainstay. AN associated with obesity responds to dietary restriction and weight loss. Drug-induced AN resolves after discontinuation of the drug. The cosmetic appear­ance of the condition can be treated with: 

  • First line: Topical retinoids act by reducing hyperkeratosis.
  • Second line: Topical keratolytics like salicylic acid are used.
  • Third line: Oral isotretinoin is used for extensive cases.

Other options:

Option A: Pellagra is caused to niacin deficiency and presents as dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. The dermatitis of pellagra is an intermittent, painful, or pruritic erythema and edema in sun-exposed areas. It gradually becomes a sharply marginated, hyperpigmented keratotic plaque. It commonly affects the dorsum of the hands.

Option C: Melasma is seen as hyperpigmented macules on the face which become more pronounced after sun exposure.

Option D: Lentiginosis is when lentigines (benign hyperpigmented macules that do not fade on UV exposure) are present in exceptionally large numbers or when they occur in a distinctive distribution.

questions.text:
Which of the following conditions are caused by infection with Pseudomonas?
  1. Ecthyma gangrenosum
  2. Hot tub folliculitis
  3. Myiasis
  4. Green nail syndrome
  5. Erythrasma
questions.solution:
Ecthyma gangrenosum, hot tub folliculitis, and green nail syndrome (1, 2, and 4) are diseases caused by Pseudomonas species. 

Pseudomonas species are gram-negative rods that cause a variety of infections depending on the site and underlying condition of the patient. They colonize burns, ulcers, and other moist skin lesions. It is mainly a nosocomial pathogen.

Ecthyma gangrenosum (Option A) is a Pseudomonas infection that is seen in severely ill, debilitated patients with burns, leukemias, or other chronic diseases. The lesions are tense, opalescent vesicles or pustules surrounded by narrow violaceous halos. The lesions become hemorrhagic and rupture, forming ulcers with necrotic black centers. The common sites are the buttocks and extremities.

The image below shows ecthyma gangrenosum. 

 

Hot tub folliculitis (Option B) presents pruritic maculopapular vesicles or pustules that may appear 1-4 days after bathing in a hot tub. It may be associated with fever, sore throat, headache, and malaise. Lesions are seen on the sides of the trunk, axillae, breasts, buttocks, and proximal extremities. As the water temperature increases, free chlorine levels drop and Pseudomonas species proliferate. They colonize bathing suits and lead to folliculitis. 

The image below shows hot tub folliculitis:

Green nail syndrome (Option D) is characterized by onycholysis of the distal portion of the nail with a striking greenish discoloration in the separated parts of the nail. This greenish discoloration is due to the pigments produced by P. aeruginosa.

Green foot syndrome results from the colonization of rubber shoes with P. aeruginosa, leading to greenish staining of the foot and toenails.

Other options:

Option 3: Myiasis is the infestation of human tissue by fly larvae. It presents as an itching pink papule that is succeeded by the formation of a tortuous line that extends by 1–30 cm a day. Treatment involves the removal of maggots of the fly from the site of infestation.

Option 5: Erythrasma is caused by the diphtheroid Corynebacterium minutissimum. It is characterized by sharply defined, dry, brown, slightly scaling patches in the intertriginous areas. Wood's lamp examination of the affected area shows coral-red fluorescence.

questions.text: The biopsy from an indurated plaque-like lesion is shown below. Keeping the diagnosis in mind, all of the following are premalignant lesions of this condition, except:
questions.solution:
The above image shows malignant cells resembling normal squamous epithelial cells with individual cell keratinization and nests of keratin pearls suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). Keratoacanthoma is considered a form of well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, not a premalignant condition.

Primary cutaneous SCC is a malignant tumor arising from epidermal keratinocytes or their appendages. The white population and people more than 85 years of age are at a greater risk of developing primary cutaneous SCC. Often, mutations of TP53 caused by ultraviolet rays leading to the formation of pyrimidine dimers are seen in SCC. HPV infection also predisposes to a greater risk of developing SCC

SCC often arises in photodamaged skin as a firm plaque‐like, verrucous ulcerated lesion. The lesion is surrounded by induration that usually extends beyond the visible margin of the lesion. 

SCCs with high‐risk features have a greater potential for local invasion and developing metastases. The clinical features of a high-risk SCC are summarised below:

  • Diameter of lesion greater than 2 cm
  • State of immunosuppression
  • SCC over the ear, lip, eyelid, and scalp.
  • SCC arising in burns, scars, chronic ulceration, and radiation damage

First-line treatment employs surgical techniques such as:

  • Curettage and cautery for low-risk SCC
  • Surgical excision for high-risk SCC. 

Option A: Actinic keratosis is characterized by hyperkeratotic lesions that have a low risk of progression to invasive SCC.

Option B: Bowen disease is a form of intraepidermal (in situ) SCC. It characteristically presents as persistent, non‐elevated, plaque(red, scaly, or crusted). It has a small potential for invasive malignancy. 

Option C: Arsenical keratosis: A corn‐like, punctate keratosis caused by arsenic, characteristically affecting the palms and soles, which may progress to squamous cell carcinoma.

Related Pearl: Risk Factors for Squamous Cell Carcinoma

Risk factors for squamous cell carcinoma

    2. Physical agents such as ionizing radiation

questions.text:
Which of the following are not primary skin lesions?
  1. Pustule
  2. Nodule
  3. Erosion
  4. Tumor
  5. Crust
questions.solution:
Erosions and crusts are not primary skin lesions. They are secondary skin lesions.

Erosion refers to the loss of the epidermis without loss of the dermis. It heals without scarring. It commonly follows a blister. 

Crusts are dried exudates of body fluids like sebum, pus, or blood that may contain bacterial debri and epithelial cells. They may be serous crusts, appearing yellow or hemorrhagic crusts, appearing red.

Other options: 

Option 1: A pustule is a primary skin lesion. It refers to a circumscribed lesion containing purulent material, that may occur within a pilosebaceous follicle, a sweat duct, or on glabrous skin. Pustules usually occur due to infections.

The image below shows circumscribed purulent lesion, suggestive of a pustule.

Option 2: Nodule, a primary skin lesion is a solid palpable lesion in the dermis or subcutis, which can be observed as an elevation or can be palpated. They are larger than 0.5cm in diameter.

The image below shows a nodule:

 

Option 4: A tumor is a primary skin lesion that is of various sizes and shapes, but usually is greater than 5 cm in diameter. They can be soft or firm, freely movable or fixed masses. General usage dictates that the word tumor means a neoplasm.

questions.text: A 4-month-old boy presents with hypotonia, seizures, and failure to thrive.  His hair is short, lusterless, & thin and the trichogram is as below. Which of the following is true about the underlying condition?

choices.text: Low serum copper and ceruloplasmin levels
Gene mutated is ATP7B on X chromosome

questions.solution:
The given clinical features and trichogram image showing pili torti suggest a diagnosis of Menke's syndrome. Low serum copper and ceruloplasmin levels are typically associated with it. In pili torti, the hair shaft is flattened at irregular intervals and has 180° twists around its long axis.

Menkes disease, also called steely hair disease, is an X‐linked recessive(not dominant) disorder caused by a mutation of a copper transporting polypeptide.

Menkes disease is a rare X-linked recessive progressive multisystemic disease of copper metabolism. It is caused by defective lysyl oxidase(not glutathione peroxidase) enzyme. This results from a deficiency of its co-factor i.e copper due to a defect in the ATP7A(not ATP7B) gene on chromosome X, which prevents the absorption of copper from the intestine.

Clinical manifestations:

  • Mainly affect males.
  • At birth, the child presents with non-specific symptoms of hypoglycemia, hypothermia, prolonged jaundice, cephalohematoma, and pectus excavatum.
  • The typical symptoms usually start by two months with characteristic skin, hair, and neurological findings. 
    • Kinky, light-colored, easily breakable hair
    • Dry skin
    • Progressive nervous system decline
    • Seizures
    • Low muscle tone (hypotonia)
    • Twisted blood vessels (arterial tortuosities)
    • Characteristic facial features, micrognathia, cutis laxa, blue iris
    • Bladder sacs or pouches (diverticula)
  • Patients usually exhibit a severe clinical course with death in early childhood.

Investigations:

  • Low serum copper and ceruloplasmin levels 
  • Neuroimaging (MRI or MRA brain) shows cerebral atrophy, delayed myelination, subdural effusion, hematoma and hygroma, leukoencephalopathy, basal ganglia signal changes, and intracranial vessel tortuosity.
  • EEG, X-ray, and molecular genetic testing aid in the diagnosis of Menke's disease.

Treatment:

  • Subcutaneous or intravenous copper-histidine is the most effective treatment.
  • Multidisciplinary approach in the management of complications
    • feeding tube to ensure proper nutrition
    • surgical correction for bladder diverticula
    • seizure management with multiple antiepileptics
    • physical, occupational, and speech therapies

Note :

  • ATP7A: Menkes disease - X-linked                 
  • ATP7B: Wilson's disease - Autosomal recessive (Chromosome 13)

 

Related Pearl: Menkes disease

questions.text: An 11-month-old infant is brought with the given finding for the past 1 month. On examination, accentuated palmar creases are also noted. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image above shows a thickened fish-scale appearance of the skin in an 11-month-old with accentuated palmar creases, suggestive of ichthyosis vulgaris.

Ichthyosis vulgaris is an inherited condition due to a mutation in the filaggrin gene (FLG). It does not present at birth but develops in the first few months of life.

Patients exhibit accentuated palmar and plantar creases and have dry scaly skin. The scales appear light grey and cover the extensor surfaces of the limbs and the trunk. It usually spares the groin and larger flexures. 

Immunohistochemistry reveals an absent or markedly reduced filaggrin signal. 

Patients benefit from the application of hydrating ointments like glycerol-containing creams.

Other Options:

Option B: Xerosis cutis is a term used to describe an acquired abnormality of the skin which has lost its normal soft smooth surface and feels dry and rough to the touch. It is seen in old age and occurs due to the deficiency of stratum corneum lipids.

Option C: Pityriasis rosea is an acute self‐limiting disease, commonly due to viral infection. It is characterized by a herald patch which is a sharply defined, erythematous, plaque. After an interval, an eruption of discrete oval dull-pink lesions, covered by fine dry silvery‐grey scales appears. The long axes of the lesions follow a Christmas tree pattern.

Option D: Harlequin ichthyosis is a lethal disease occurring due to frameshift mutations. It presents as a shiny parchment‐like membrane covering a neonate completely. This membrane cracks within a few days after birth and usually peels off within the first 4 weeks of life. The following image shows Harlequin ichthyosis:

questions.text: A patient with no co-morbidities is brought to the OPD with complaints of lesions as shown in the image below. The vitals and systemic examination is normal. What is the preferred treatment for this case?
questions.solution:
The image above shows the accumulation of white curdy material in the oral cavity suggesting a diagnosis of oral candidiasis. The preferred treatment, in this case, is topical nystatin. 

To treat oral candidiasis, topical suspensions of nystatin, amphotericin, or miconazole gel applied several times a day can be used.

Nystatin acts by damaging the fungal cell membrane by binding irreversibly to ergosterol. It is fungistatic at low concentrations and fungicidal at high concentrations. It is available in wide a range of formulations such as cream, ointment, pessaries, and oral suspension.

Other options:

Option B: Whitfield’s ointment is a topically used combination of 6% benzoic acid and 3% salicylic acid in a petrolatum base. It is effective in the treatment of superficial dermatophyte infections.

Option C: Oral itraconazole is used in oral candidosis that fails to respond to topical therapy and in patients with AIDS.

Option D: Intravenous amphotericin B compounds, including a liposomal formulation, are administered in systemically ill patients.

questions.text: A patient with seizures, low IQ, and the following skin findings was suspected to have hypomelanosis of Ito. What is the pattern of distribution of these hypopigmented lesions?
questions.solution:
The hypomelanosis of Ito usually corresponds to the lines of Blaschko. The image above shows cutaneous macular hypopigmented whorls, streaks, and patches seen in hypomelanosis of Ito.

Hypomelanosis of Ito is a rare neuroectodermal disorder of pigmentation. It is associated with seizures and mental impairment. Cutaneous abnormalities are characterized by unilateral or bilateral macular hypopigmented whorls, streaks, and patches, along the lines of Blaschko. Extracutaneous findings include neurological, ophthalmological, and skeletal defects.

Blaschko's lines are lines of normal developmental growth patterns in the skin. They do not correspond to any known nervous, vascular, or lymphatic structures. Other conditions that are distributed along these lines include epidermal nevi, and incontinentia pigmenti.

Other options:

Option A: Lesions distributed along lines of lymphatics are seen in lymphangitis and sporotrichosis

Option B: Lesions distributed along lines of blood vessels are seen in thrombophlebitis, Mondor disease (linear thrombophlebitis on the trunk), eczema related to varicose veins, and temporal arteritis.

Option C: Lesions distributed along nerve trunks are seen in leprosy.

questions.text: A preterm neonate born to an HIV-positive mother was admitted to the NICU with septicemia. On examination, a diffuse pustular rash is seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical clincher with septicemia and pustular skin rash seen in a neonate born to an HIV-positive mother suggests a likely diagnosis of neonatal listeriosis. 

Neonatal listeriosis is caused by Listeria monocytogenes. Transplacental infection of the fetus is common. Maternal HIV infection predisposes to neonatal listeriosis.

Clinically, there are two forms of neonatal listeriosis:

  • The early‐onset form is a predominantly septicemic form and commonly presents as neonatal sepsis with skin rash within 5 days of birth. The rash appears as grey-white papules or pustules.
  • The late-onset form of the disease presents as meningitis usually occurring usually after 5 days but before 30 days of birth. 

Diagnosis is made by culturing the organism from cerebrospinal fluid, or blood. Hematological examination shows increased peripheral blood monocytes.

Treatment is done using parenteral ampicillin with an aminoglycoside like gentamicin.

Other Options:

Miliaria crystallina, toxic erythema of the newborn and transient pustular melanosis are all benign findings seen in a neonate.

Option A: Miliaria crystallina presents during the first few weeks of life as crops of clear, thin‐walled, superficial vesicles resembling drops of water. It improves spontaneously as the sweat ducts mature, in a few weeks.

The image below shows a picture of miliaria crystallina:

Option B: Toxic erythema of the newborn (erythema toxicum neonatorum) is a common, transient, blotchy, red macular rash (sometimes with small pustules) seen in the first few days of life. The infant is well, and there are no complications. It spontaneously resolves in around 3 days.

The image below shows a picture of erythema toxicum neonatorum: 

Option D: Transient pustular melanosis presents at birth as a characteristic eruption of flaccid, superficial, fragile pustules, with no surrounding erythema. No treatment is required and it is self resolving.

The image below shows transient pustular melanosis in a newborn:

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient on multiple drugs developed a well-defined, round reddish-brown lesion on his lips. He gives a history of taking an over-the-counter drug recently and mentions that he had a similar lesion on his lips in the past that resolved spontaneously. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a well-defined, round reddish-brown lesion on the lips along with the history of similar episodes in the past which resolved spontaneously suggests a likely diagnosis of fixed drug eruption and the most likely cause is ibuprofen.

Fixed drug eruptions (FDE) are cutaneous adverse reactions to certain drugs. They are characterized by sharply demarcated dull red to brown lesions. They occur in lips, hands, legs, face, genitalia, and oral mucosa, and cause a burning sensation. The lesion recurs in the same locations upon re-exposure to the offending drug.

Drugs that are commonly known to cause fixed drug eruptions include co‐trimoxazole, NSAIDs, tetracyclines, barbiturates, phenolphthalein in laxatives, etc. Drug-specific clinical patterns may also occur. These include lesions on the lips and genitals due to NSAIDs and lesions on genitals due to tetracyclines.

Oral provocation of the implicated drug is the gold standard to confirm drug causality. A patch test can help in diagnosis. 

Treatment involves stopping the offending drug and the use of topical corticosteroids.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with depigmented macules with fine scaling over the trunk, suggestive of pityriasis versicolor. The doctor used the instrument seen in the image below to confirm the suspected diagnosis. Identify the instrument and likely findings in this case.
questions.solution:
The instrument is the handheld Wood's ultraviolet lamp and the finding for a case of pityriasis versicolor is yellow fluorescence.

Pityriasis versicolor is a mild, chronic infection caused by Malassezia. It is characterized by discrete or confluent, depigmented areas, with fine scaling mostly on the upper trunk. There are patchy and varying skin color changes, with occasional mild irritation. 

On Wood's lamp examination, pityriasis versicolor lesions show yellow fluorescence. Wood's lamp examination is a source of ultraviolet light from which virtually all visible rays have been excluded by a Wood’s filter (nickel oxide).

The image below shows the yellow fluorescence seen in Pityriasis Versicolor.

 

Other options:

Options A and B: Dermoscopes are extensions of simple magnification, having built‐in illumination. They are applied to the skin surface with a film of oil on the lesion to enhance the visibility of subcorneal structures. They are mainly used to diagnose doubtful pigmented lesions. Trichoscopy refers to the use of dermoscopy for hair and scalp lesions.

Starburst appearance dermoscopy is seen in Spitz nevi and Reed nevi. Reticular appearance on dermoscopy is seen in various congenital nevi, junctional nevi, and compound nevi.

The image below shows a handheld dermoscope:

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: Groove sign of Greenblatt is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The groove sign of Greenblatt is seen in cases of lymphogranuloma venerum (LGV). 

It is a pathognomonic sign of LGV in which a groove-like depression is seen between femoral and inguinal lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament.

LGV is a sexually transmitted disease caused by serovars L1-L3 of Chlamydia trachomatis

Patients present with genital ulcers, inguinal swelling or rectal discharge, and bleeding. The disease occurs in 3 stages. The primary stage is characterized by the appearance of a single, non‐indurated, shallow genital ulcer. This heals rapidly and leaves no scar. In the secondary stage of LGV, along with the groove sign, unilateral lymphadenopathy and painful enlargement of glands in the form of buboes are seen. The tertiary stage occurs in chronic untreated lesions and consists of genital edema, polypoid growths, fistulae, ulceration and scarring.

The detection of serovar L of Chlamydia trachomatis from the site of infection confirms the diagnosis. This is done by nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs) and confirmed by real‐time polymerase chain reaction (PCR) assays for LGV‐specific DNA. In earlier times, the Frei test, which showed a positive cutaneous hypersensitivity reaction to purified chlamydial antigen was done but is now obsolete.

Treatment:

First-line treatment employs the administration of oral doxycycline 100 mg given twice daily for 21 days and the patient should be thoroughly investigated to exclude other STIs.

Fluctuant buboes may require aspiration but the surgical incision is usually contraindicated. Recent sexual partners of the patient should also be notified.

The image below shows the groove sign.

Other options:

Option B: Syphilis is primarily a sexually transmitted disease caused by Treponema palladium but vertical transmission is also possible. It commonly presents as a hard, painless genital ulcer with induration, followed by the development of rubbery enlargement of inguinal lymph nodes.

Option C: Gonorrhoea is primarily a sexually transmitted bacterial infection caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae but vertical transmission during childbirth can occur. questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient presented with urinary frequency and copious frothy vaginal discharge. On per speculum examination, a strawberry cervix was seen. What is the first-line treatment?

choices.text: Doxycycline 100 mg capsule OD for 14 days
Clotrimazole 100 mg vaginal tablet OD for 7 days
Metronidazole 2 g tablet as a single oral dose
Ketoconazole 400 mg OD daily for 5 days

questions.solution:
The above examination finding of strawberry cervix (punctate hemorrhages over the cervix) with a history of copious frothy vaginal discharge is suggestive of trichomoniasis. The first-line treatment for this condition is metronidazole as a single oral dose of 2g. 

Trichomonas vaginalis is one of the most common causes of vaginal discharge. Trichomonas infection of the female genital tract causes the following symptoms:

  • Foul-smelling, frothy, greenish-yellow discharge per vaginum with pH > 4.5,
  • Vulval pruritis
  • Dysuria and urinary frequency

Males can have asymptomatic urethritis. 

Diagnosis in females is usually easily confirmed by the presence of motile organisms on a wet film. Culture in Feinberg–Whittington medium is the most reliable method. More sensitive tests like PCR and NAAT are now available.

Treatment:

  • Treatment with metronidazole 2 g single oral dose is prescribed and patients should also be evaluated for concurrent gonorrhea and Chlamydia infection.
  • Even though identification of the organism in partners is not necessary, all sexual partners should be treated. 
  • Patients and their recent sexual partners should be advised to abstain from intercourse or use a condom during therapy

Other options:

Option A, Option B, and Option D: Doxycycline, clotrimazole, and ketoconazole do not eradicate Trichomonas vaginalis.

questions.text: The biopsy of a patient suspected to have a type of cutaneous T cell lymphoma is shown below. The patient presented with erythematous, scaly polymorphic patches and plaques on the limbs. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The biopsy image of lymphocytic infiltration of the epidermis with Pautrier's microabscesses, in a patient suspected to have a type of cutaneous T cell lymphoma with erythematous, scaly polymorphic patches and plaques on the limbs is suggestive of mycosis fungoides.

Pautrier's microabscess refers to clusters of atypical lymphocytes in the epidermis with the absence of spongiosis. It is seen in mycosis fungoides. 

Mycosis fungoides is the most common variant of primary cutaneous T cell lymphoma. It is characterized by polymorphic patches and plaques with fine scaling usually present on the limbs, the breast, and buttock areas. The lesions may be pruritic, but in some patients, they are asymptomatic.

Skin biopsies from the patches or plaques show lymphocytic infiltrate in the papillary dermis. Spongiosis is usually absent. There may be an accumulation of atypical T cells along with the basal layer in the epidermis, either singly or in clusters. The clusters of atypical lymphocytes in the epidermis are known as Pautrier microabscesses. The malignant T cells appear cerebriform, heavily stained and have irregular nuclear outlines.

Other options :

Option A: In chronic psoriasis, Munro's microabscesses are seen. They are neutrophilic microabscesses that are found in the stratum corneum. Other features like irregular epidermal thickening and parakeratosis may also be present.
 
The image below shows epidermal hyperplasia with loss of the granular cell layer, parakeratosis, and Munro’s microabscesses suggestive of psoriasis.
 
 
Option B: The histological changes in lichen planus include increased Langerhans cells in the epidermis, spongiosis, and sawtooth appearance of Rete ridges. A fully developed lichen planus papule shows acanthosis of the epidermis, thickening of the granular layer, and hyperkeratosis. The image below shows the histopathological changes in lichen planus.
 

 

Option C: The histological changes in pemphigus vulgaris include the presence of suprabasal clefts and blisters. The basal cells stay attached to the basement membrane but are separate from each other, appearing like a row of tombstones.

questions.text: A 20-month-old male patient with a history of seizures and a CT scan showing tram-track calcifications is suspected to have Sturge-Weber syndrome. Which of the following is a dermatological finding of this condition?
questions.solution:
A port-wine stain is the dermatological finding seen in Sturge-Weber syndrome (SWS). 

SWS is a severe neurocutaneous disorder. Patients have a capillary malformation on the face (port-wine stain) and brain (leptomeninges), as well as abnormal eye blood vessels leading to glaucoma. The capillary malformation or port wine stain appears as a homogenous, pink, red, or purple macule, present at birth. Most children with intracranial vascular anomalies present with seizures before the age of two. Patients also may have hemiparesis, stroke-like episodes, headaches, and developmental delay.

The image below shows prominent subcortical white matter calcification seen in this disease:

 

 A port-wine stain on the face is shown below.

 

 

Treatment of the cutaneous vascular lesion can be done by a pulsed-dye laser. Seizures and glaucoma should also be treated.

Other Options:

Option A: Infantile hemangioma is a common benign vascular tumor in childhood. It presents anywhere on the body and is usually not present at birth. They appear red or maroon if superficial, and bluish if deep. They regress by 4 years of age usually. It is shown in the image below.

 

 

Option C: Becker’s nevus presents as a hyperpigmented, hypertrichosis patch on the upper trunk and usually begins just before puberty. It is shown below.

 

 

Option D: Nevus spilus presents as light-brown macules or papules. It frequently occurs on the trunk, lower extremities and tends to follow Blaschko lines. It is shown below.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with cutaneous bumps on the hand as shown in the image below. These are pink, painless, and sometimes itchy. There is no history of close contact with animals. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is molluscum contagiosum. It can be diagnosed based on the classical pink pearly lesions with a characteristic dimple at the center (umbilicated), not associated with inflammation and necrosis.

Molluscum contagiosum is caused by a poxvirus named Molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV) which has two main variants, MCV-1 and MCV-2. . The disease most commonly occurs in early childhood between the age of 2-5 years. 

It has an incubation period of 2 weeks to 6 months. The lesions are shiny, pearly white, hemispherical, umbilicated papules that may show a central pore. These may enlarge slowly. In children, lesions are more often seen on the limbs. In teenagers and young adults, the mode of transmission is usually sexual, leading to anogenital lesions. Widespread and refractory lesions are seen most commonly in HIV or patients on immunosuppressive therapy. The majority of the lesions resolve spontaneously within some months, while some may persist for years.

The diagnosis is usually clear when multiple lesions at different stages of evolution are seen and the classical umbilicated papule is observed. Diagnosis can be confirmed by direct microscopy, histopathology, or molecular analysis.

Treatment is usually not required and lesions are likely to resolve spontaneously.

Other options: 

Option A: Keratoacanthoma is a rapidly evolving tumor of the skin now classified as a well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. It mostly presents as a solitary firm, rounded, reddish-papule with a horny plug in the center. It may also be covered by a crust covering a keratinized crate. The most frequently affected area is the central part of the face like the nose, cheeks, eyelids, and lips.

The below image shows keratoacanthoma.

 

Option B: Cowpox disease is caused by orthopoxvirus and presents as inflammatory vesicular lesions which form crusts and heal with superficial scarring. The lesions develop around 5 to 7 days following contact with an infected animal.

Option C: Milker's nodule presents as a small papule that develops into a reddish‐blue, firm nodule that may appear vesicular. It is often surrounded by a ring of erythema around the lesion. Multiple or solitary lesions are found most commonly on the hands, forearms, and occasionally on the face.

This infection affects those in close contact with animals harboring the virus, especially farmers, milkers, and veterinary personnel.

The following image shows milker's nodules.

Phrynoderma, which is characterized by the presence of keratotic follicular papules over anterolateral thighs and posterolateral upper arms, is also seen.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with an itchy elevated lesion on her face as shown in the image. On dermoscopy, there is an atypical pigmented network. Which of the following will be the best indicator to assess the prognosis of this disease?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an asymmetrical pigmented lesion on the face with an irregular border suggestive of malignant melanoma. The best prognostic factor in primary melanoma is provided by the tumor thickness, the Breslow index.

Malignant melanomas are malignant tumors arising from melanocytes.

Breslow index is a measure of the distance between the overlying epidermal granular layer and the deepest level of invasion of the primary melanoma.

Other prognostic factors for primary melanoma:

  • Sentinel node status
  • Ulceration
  • Mitotic rate of cells
  • Age of the patient (negative for older age)
  • Sex of the patient (negative for males)
  • Site of the lesion(negative for head and neck)

Other options:

Options A and C: Age (young) and sex (female) respectively are favorable prognostic factors in the above clinical scenario.

Option D: Lymphovascular invasion has a role to play in assessing the prognosis of primary melanoma. However, Breslow's index is the best prognostic factor.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with HIV presents with the following skin lesions over the distal portion of his lower limbs. The biopsy of the lesion appears as below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Multifocal erythematous patches and plaques over the limb in a patient with HIV, along with the histopathological image showing sheets of whorled spindle cells, are highly suggestive of Kaposi sarcoma.

Kaposi sarcoma is a multifocal endothelial proliferation of low‐grade malignant potential. It is seen in high association with AIDS (acquired immunodeficiency syndrome) and human Herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8).

Classic Kaposi sarcoma occurs in older men of Eastern European and Meditteranean descent. It has the following three clinical stages:

  • Patch stage
  • Plaque stage
  • Nodules/ tumor stage

Histopathological examination shows a circumscribed tumor nodule occupying the dermis with a dense and whorled arrangement of spindled cells. Erythrocyte extravasation within slit‐like spaces is prominent, with readily observed mitoses and eosinophilic globules. 

The given image shows sheets of proliferating spindle cells seen in Kaposi's sarcoma:

In patch‐stage KS, normal vessels or adnexa are ensheathed within new abnormal vascular spaces. This is called the promontory sign. This happens due to the proliferation of blood vessels through collagen bundles around the adnexa and surrounding pre‐existing vessels.

The image below shows the promontory sign seen in Kaposi's sarcoma:

There is no definitive cure, but KS is highly radiosensitive and achieves complete response in most cases. In AIDS‐associated KS, instituting highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) often (but not always) results in regression of KS. In localized cutaneous KS, excision and cryotherapy can be used.

For advanced KS, liposomal doxorubicin has recently been approved by the US Food and Drug Administration as a first-line treatment.

Other Options:

Option A: Hereditary haemorrhagic telangiectasia is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by mucocutaneous and gastrointestinal telangiectasias. It is associated with vascular malformations in the lungs, liver, or brain.

Option C: Bacillary angiomatosis is also seen in immunosuppressed patients. It is characterized by solitary or crops of small papules of dermal nodules that involve any site or mucosal surface. Local lymphadenopathy may be present. 

Option D: Angioma serpiginosum is a benign and asymptomatic naevoid disorder affecting the small vessels of the upper dermis. It presents as small red punctae in a cluster. It commonly occurs in linear, serpiginous, or annular patterns.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady, who was recently started on OCPs is referred to the dermatology OPD with hyperpigmented macules on the upper lip, malar region, and the forehead. It is exacerbated by sun exposure. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this lady on OCP with hyperpigmented macules over the face is melasma. 

Melasma is the most common cause of facial melanosis that manifests as hyperpigmented macules on the face. It is exacerbated by sun exposure and oral contraceptive pills. The condition is predominantly seen in females. Melasma is very common in the 3rd trimester of pregnancy and is most marked in brunettes. It is due to increased levels of estrogen and progesterone, stimulating the activity of melanocytes. Histopathology shows no increase in but hyper-functional melanocytes. It resolves on its own after pregnancy. Hypermelanosis affects mainly the upper lip, the malar regions, forehead, and chin. It is more common in women between 20 and 40 years. 

Wood's lamp examination is useful to differentiate the level of pigmentation and treatment response:  

  • Epidermal melasma- shows enhanced color contrast 
  • Dermal melasma- shows less color contrast (more resistant to treatment)
  • Mixed melasma.

Melasma is more chronic and requires treatment with depigmenting agents like:

  • Kligman's triple combination - topical hydroquinone + tretinoin + corticosteroid compound cream (first line)
  • Hydroquinone (reduces tyrosinase activity)
  • Kojic acid (tyrosinase inhibitor)
  • Chemical peels

Other options :

Option A: Naevus of Ota presents as a bluish melanocytosis affecting the sclera and skin adjacent to the eye in the distribution of the first and second branches of the trigeminal nerve. 

Option B: Inherited lentiginosis has its onset in infancy or childhood, Lentiginosis refers to pigmented macules present in exceptionally large numbers or when they occur in a distinctive distribution. These macules called lentigo have an increased number of melanocytes.

Option C: Ephelides as light‐brown pigmented macules. They first appear at about the age of 5 years and are seen on the light-exposed skin of fair‐skinned individuals.
