questions.text:
A girl presented with itching and oozing from a lesion on the ear after wearing nickel earrings. Identify the correct statements about the test used to confirm the diagnosis.
  1. Based on delayed hypersensitivity reaction
  2. Eczematous disorders unresponsive to treatment is an indication
  3. Testing should be delayed for 4 weeks following sunbathing
  4. Low-dose steroids hamper the positive response and are a contraindication for the test
  5. The optimum site for the test is the abdomen
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described above is suggestive of allergic contact dermatitis to nickel. The test used to confirm the diagnosis is the patch test and statements 1,2 and 3 are the correct statements regarding it. 

The patch test is used to detect delayed (type IV) hypersensitivity (Statement 1) to antigens that come in contact with the skin, by applying the suspected antigen under occlusive patches to the skin. Patches are removed after 48 hours (or sooner if there is itching and burning). The patch site is evaluated 1 hour after removal, on day 2, and on day 4 to detect delayed reactions.

Site- Usually the upper back, or lateral aspect of the arm. The abdomen and thigh are less suitable sites, that are very rarely used.

Indications for patch testing:

  • Allergic contact dermatitis
  • Eczematous disorders where contact allergy is suspected
  • Eczematous disorders not responding to treatment (Statement 2)
  • Chronic hand and foot eczema
  • Varicose eczema

Patch test should be delayed for 4 weeks after sunbathing (Statement 3), and the patches should not be exposed to the sun or any other UV light. Corticosteroids and other immunosuppressive drugs may result in false negatives in sensitized patients. They should be stopped before the patch test, if feasible. However, at doses below 15 mg of prednisolone, the response is not likely to be affected.

questions.text: A 32-year-old fisherman presented to the clinic with complaints of pain and swelling over the left middle finger for 2 days as shown in the image given below. Tenderness is elicited over the affected nail on examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with the image showing erythema and swelling around the nail folds is suggestive of acute paronychia with abscess. Abscess in paronychia requires immediate incision and drainage.

Paronychia refers to an infection of the proximal, lateral finger and toe nail folds. It results from the disruption of the protective barrier between the nail and the nail fold, introducing pathogens and predisposing the area to infection. Paronychia is more common in women than in men. It can be acute if it lasts less than six weeks or chronic if it lasts for more than six weeks.

In addition to infectious causes, papulosquamous disorders like psoriasis and pemphigus also can cause paronychia. Certain factors that predispose to paronychia include:

  • Certain occupations like dishwasher, bartender, housekeeper
  • Certain medications like retinoids, protease inhibitors
  • Immunosuppressive states like diabetes, HIV, malignancy

Paronychia is diagnosed based on clinical presentation. Clinical features vary with respect to the presentation.

Acute paronychia:

  • Erythematous, swollen, and tender lateral nail fold
  • Area of fluctuance if an abscess is present - positive digital pressure test

A digital pressure test is used to assess if an abscess is present or not. Pressure is applied to the volar aspect of the involved digit. A larger than expected area of blanching will be visible at the paronychia if an abscess is present and drainage will be needed.

The image below shows acute paronychia of a fingernail.

Chronic paronychia:

  • Nail fold may be red, swollen or boggy
  • Nail plate may be thickened and discoloured
  • Retraction of the proximal nail fold
  • Nail dystrophy
  • Loss of the cuticle
  • Fluctuance is rare on digital pressure test

Management involves:

  • Non-pharmacological measures like:
    • Patients should keep their hands dry and warm
    • Wear gloves for any recurrent contact with water, chemicals, and irritants
    • Avoid trauma to the hands as much as possible
    • Avoid nail-biting or manicuring nail folds until complete recovery
    • Warm soaks using antiseptics or antibiotic solutions for 10 to 15 minutes, multiple times a day.
  • Antibiotic coverage depends on the type of paronychia.
    • Acute paronychia: Since acute paronychias are mostly caused by Staphylococcus aureus, adequate coverage is required in the form of:
      • Topical antibiotics: Triple antibiotic ointment, bacitracin, or mupirocin
      • Oral antibiotics:
        • Dicloxacillin 250mg four times a day
        • Cephalexin 500mg three to four times a day.
      • If suspecting MRSA:
        • Clindamycin 300 to 450mg four times a day
        • Doxycycline 100mg twice a day
    • Anaerobic coverage requires the addition of clindamycin or amoxicillin-clavulanate, in cases of suspected oral inoculation.
    • Chronic paronychia: Topical and systemic antifungal agents such as itraconazole and terbinafine are used to cover Candida species.
    • Topical tacrolimus ointment is effective in case of allergic and atopic contact dermatitis causing chronic paronychia
  • Presence of abscess warrants immediate incision and drainage under local/digital block. Partial or complete nail plate removal may be needed.
  • Surgical management of chronic paronychia involves procedures like:
    • Eponychial marsupialisation: A crescent-shaped incision parallel to the distal edge of eponychium, exteriorises the infected and obstructed nail matrix and allows its drainage.
    • En-bloc excision of the proximal nail fold
    • Swiss roll technique: Nail fold is elevated proximally over a non-adherent dressing, rolled up and secured with sutures and dressing applied. After 48 hours, if the wound is clean, the sutures are removed and the nail fold is brought to the original position by secondary intention. This exposure of the nail bed allows the drainage of any residual infection.

Acute paronychia can cause a severe infection of the hand and may spread to involve underlying tendons and spaces of the hand. Infections of the:

  • Ring and middle finger spread into the mid-palmar space
  • Index finger to thenar space
  • Little finger spread to ulnar bursa and mid palmar space.

Chronic paronychia may result in nail dystrophy, discolouration and brittle, distorted nail plates.

Acute paronychia usually resolves within a few days and will rarely recur while chronic paronychia may persist for longer and may recur.

Other options:

Subungual melanoma presents as brown to black linear discolouration in the nail bed that may later progress to inflammatory pigmented paronychia and pigmentation of the adjacent skin. The age of onset is usually between the sixth and seventh decade of life. Patients do not suspect it to be cancer usually and by the time they present, the melanoma is already advanced and carries a poor prognosis.

The image below shows a picture of nail melanoma.

Herpetic whitlow is caused by Herpes simplex virus and presents as multiple crops of painful deep vesicles. These vesicles coalesce to form a honeycombed appearance or a large bulla.

The image below shows cloudy blisters and vesicles seen in herpetic whitlow.

Terry's nail is a term used to describe nails that are proximally white and distally normal. They can be due to cirrhosis, congestive cardiac failure or diabetes.

Small round cells with granular chromatin and scant cytoplasm

questions.solution:
The image above shows a central ulcer with raised borders and rolled-out edges (rodent ulcer) suggesting a diagnosis of basal cell carcinoma. Characteristic peripheral palisading of tumor cells is seen in this condition.

The image below shows tumors that resemble cells of the stratum basale that have grown into the dermis. This cluster of cells is surrounded at the periphery by perpendicularly arranged cells (peripheral palisading of tumor cells). 


Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is a cancer of cells of the basal layer of the skin. It is the most common human cancer. Various clinical variants are seen but nodular basal cell carcinoma is the most common sub-type. It commonly presents on the head and neck as a flesh-colored mass. The lesion usually becomes more irregular as it grows.  

Management involves surgical excision with a predetermined margin. Complete clearance can be achieved in most cases of well‐defined small BCC with a 4–5 mm surgical margin.

Topical 5% imiquimod cream is also very effective in the treatment of BCC. It stimulates toll‐like receptors 7 and 8 which promote Th1 innate and adaptive cell‐mediated immune responses for recognition and destruction of the tumor cells.

Other options:

Option A: Large tumour cells with keratinisation showing invasion of the basement membrane of the epidermis are seen in squamous cell carcinoma. Tumour cells are usually large, polygonal with abundant cytoplasm and vesicular nuclei.

Option C: Nests of tumour cells with pagetoid (upward) spread are seen in malignant melanoma. It is very common in the nodular variant of melanoma where horizontal and vertical growth of tumour cells occurs.

Option D: Uniform small round cells having fine/granular chromatin and scant cytoplasm are seen in Merkel cell carcinoma, a neuroendocrine skin cancer. These cells are located in the epithelial basal cell layer and have neuroendocrine and mechanoreceptor functions.

questions.text: A 7-month-old child is brought by his parents with the following lesions for one week. On examination, Darier's sign is positive. Lesions are not seen in the palms, soles and face. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient with positive Darier's sign and reddish‐brown maculopapular lesions on the trunk is urticaria pigmentosa. 

Urticaria pigmentosa is the most common type of cutaneous mastocytosis. It occurs due to an increased number of mast cells in the skin. The symptoms occur due to the release of mast cell-derived mediators. The age of onset is in the first year in the childhood type and 20–40 years in the adult type.

It presents with numerous reddish‐brown or pale monomorphic maculopapules, plaques, or nodules in a symmetrical distribution. Lesions can occur anywhere but are common over the trunk and thighs. The palms and soles are usually spared. Even though the neck and the hairline can be affected, the face is usually spared. It can also present with bullous lesions that heal without scarring.

Other features :

  • Flushing
  • Pruritus
  • Heat or cold intolerance
  • Recurrent diarrhea
  • Dyspepsia
  • Depression
  • Headache

Darier's sign is seen in urticaria pigmentosa. It refers to the development of urticaria and erythema around the lesions after mild trauma, including scratching or rubbing of the lesion. Darier's sign is not specific to mastocytosis as it is also rarely seen in juvenile xanthogranuloma and acute lymphoblastic leukemia.


Treatment of urticaria pigmentosa includes: 

  • Avoiding physical stimuli that trigger mast cell degranulation- temperature extremes, pressure, alcohol
  • Antihistamines
  • Mast cell stabilizers
  • Topical and oral corticosteroids
  • PUVA (Psoralen + ultraviolet light A) therapy
  • Tyrosine kinase inhibitors like imatinib.

Other options:

Option A: Café‐au‐lait macules (CALMs), also called Café‐au‐lait spots, present as well-circumscribed, hyperpigmented, light brown to dark brown macules and patches that range in size. They may appear at birth or in the first decade. They may be present on any body part, but most commonly involve the trunk and the extremities. They are associated with several genetic syndromes such as neurofibromatosis (NF1).

The image below shows Café‐au‐lait spots:


Option B: Tinea corporis is fungal infection of glabrous skin. It includes lesions of the trunk and limbs, excluding ringworms of specialized sites such as the scalp, feet, and groins. Characteristic lesions are circular, usually sharply marginated with a raised edge. 

The image below shows itchy,pink-to-red, round patches with raised scaly borders that tend to be clear in the center of tinea corporis:


Option D: Chronic bullous dermatosis (linear Ig A Dermatosis) of childhood is an autoimmune blistering disease in infants and children. The disease can also be seen in adults and is known as Linear IgA disease of adults or IgA bullous pemphigoid.

It presents as tense blisters and vesicles urticated plaques with erythema. They are arranged annularly in a “crown of jewels” formation. Varying degrees of pruritis may be present. The most common sites are the perioral area and perineum, followed by the trunk and limbs.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman who is a known case of autoimmune thyroiditis presents with complaints of hair loss over the back of her head. On examination, a 2 cm area of complete, smooth, circular hair loss with distinct margins and exclamation mark hairs is seen without scaling or inflammation. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?

choices.text: It is a T-cell mediated inflammatory disease
Topical clobetasol is used in treatment

questions.solution:
The given clinical case with complete, smooth hair loss with no scaling or no inflammation and characteristic exclamation mark hairs is suggestive of alopecia areata. This disease preferentially affects pigmented hair, not white hair (option A is not a feature of this condition).

Alopecia areata is a chronic inflammatory disease that causes non-scarring hair loss. It is a T-cell mediated inflammatory disease. It is associated with several autoimmune diseases including thyroiditis, lupus erythematosus, vitiligo, and psoriasis.

It mainly affects the scalp, but can also affect the beard, eyebrows, and eyelashes. In some cases, this progresses to a total loss of scalp hair (alopecia totalis) or a loss of all hair on the body (alopecia universalis).

The lesions of alopecia areata are characterized by a smooth circumscribed patch of alopecia. Some broken hairs can be seen which are called exclamation marks. They are easily extractable. It preferentially affects pigmented hair and spares white hair. It can cause fine stippled pitting of the nails and roughen of the nail bed, which is called trachyonychia.

Histopathology will show perifollicular and intrafollicular T lymphocyte infiltration.

Spontaneous remission occurs in a majority of the patients. Topical steroids like clobetasol can be useful in patchy alopecia areata. Intralesional steroids are the most effective treatment for patchy alopecia areata. A depot steroid-like triamcinolone administered by fine-needle injection into the upper subcutis can stimulate hair growth at the site. Multiple injections are usually required.

Severe and long-standing alopecia areata requires oral corticosteroids.

questions.text: A young woman presented with skin hardening and tightening over the fingers, hands and face. On examination, the doctor noticed findings as shown in the image given below. Which of the following is not a feature seen in her condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows a young woman with mask-like facies, stretched, shiny skin, loss of normal facial lines, microstomia, and pitted scarring on the right index finger which is suggestive of scleroderma or systemic sclerosis. Loss of sweat glands is seen in this disease and not the preservation of sweat glands.

Scleroderma is an umbrella term for the group of conditions that include both localized and systemic forms that manifest internal organ features, as well as demonstrate vascular manifestations such as the Raynaud phenomenon. There is a 4: 1 female predominance.

Two types of systemic sclerosis are limited and diffuse forms.

Cutaneous features:

  • Hands and feet - Raynaud's phenomenon, non-pitting edema, painful ulcerations which heal with pitted scars, sclerodactyly, contractures, loss of sweat glands
  • Face - mask-like facies, telangiectasia, and diffuse hyperpigmentation
  • Trunk - firm, shiny, and thickened skin

Systemic features:

  • GIT- dysphagia, GERD, diminished or abnormal motility, malabsorption
  • Lungs- pulmonary fibrosis and alveolitis
  • Heart- cardiac conduction defects, heart failure
  • Kidney- Scleroderma renal crisis, headache, fever, malaise, hypertension
  • Musculoskeletal- weakness, carpal tunnel syndrome

The image shows a woman with mask-like facies with stretched, shiny skin, and loss of normal facial lines, microstomia, and resorption of distal phalanges of the fingers:

The image below shows an acrosclerotic piece-meal necrosis of the first digit in a patient:

The progressive disappearance of fingerprints is seen in systemic sclerosis due to changes in skin elasticity, hardness, and thickness over the fingertips.

Autoantibodies detected in systemic sclerosis are antitopoisomerase 1 antibody (anti‐Scl‐70 or ATA), anticentromere antibody (ACA), anti‐RNA polymerase III antibody (ARA or RNAP).

questions.text: A 51-year-old diabetic male patient presented with a painful hard lump with purulent discharge from multiple follicular orifices as seen in the image below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a diabetic male patient presenting with a painful hard red lump with purulent discharge from multiple follicular orifices is suggestive of carbuncle.

A carbuncle is a deep infection of a contiguous group of follicles accompanied by inflammation of surrounding connective tissue. The causative organism is Staphylococcus aureus. It is commonly associated with diabetes mellitus. 

It presents as a painful hard lump in the initial stage of infection which increases in size to about 3-10 cm. This is followed by suppuration and pus is discharged from multiple follicular orifices.

Most lesions are usually solitary and are present on the back of the neck, the shoulders or the hips and thighs.

Microbiological swabs are taken from the lesion for the culture of the organisms present. Treatment with penicillinase-resistant antibiotics such as flucloxacillin is recommended. Incision and drainage or saucerisation may be required to aid the removal of pus and necrotic tissue. Lesions usually heal with scarring. 

Other options:

Option A: Folliculitis is infection and inflammation of the follicular ostium. It presents as small follicular papules or pinhead pustules which are rarely painful. They heal without scar formation.

The image below shows a picture of folliculitis:


Option B: Ecthyma is a pyogenic skin infection marked by the formation of adherent crusts beneath which ulceration occurs. It is mainly caused by Group A Streptococcus like S. pyogenes, Pseudomonas aeruginosa and S. aureus. 

On an erythematous base, small bullae or pustules are quickly covered in a hard crust of dried exudate that has an indurated base and grows larger by peripheral accretion. The crust, when removed reveals an irregular, purulent ulcer.

Option D: Furuncle or boil is an abscess of the hair follicle (usually vellus type). It presents as a small inflammatory nodule that soon becomes pustular and necrotic and eventually heals to leave a violaceous macule and a permanent scar following the discharge of a necrotic core.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presented with itching between his fingers and on the flexural part of his wrists. The mother reports that the itching is worse at night. Similar complaints are seen in the patient's sibling. On examination, inflammatory papules, excoriations, and burrows are seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in a child with itching in between fingers and flexural part of the wrists that worsens at night, with similar symptoms seen in the sibling, and examination revealing inflammatory papules, burrows, and excoriations is suggestive of scabies. 

Scabies is an ectoparasitic skin infection that is transmitted through the means of close personal contact/fomites. It is caused by the mite Sarcoptes scabiei var hominis or human itch mite. It leads to severe pruritis, excoriating papules, and burrows. The pruritis typically shows nocturnal exacerbations. In adults, the face is often spared. Typical sites include the finger webs, the flexor surfaces of the wrists, elbows, axillae, buttocks, and genitalia. The typical lesions of scabies are burrows.

The image below shows a close-up photo of a scabies burrow. The large scaly patch at the left is due to scratching. The scabies mite traveled towards the upper right and can be seen at the end of the burrow.

Diagnosis is made through clinical examination and microscopic examination of scrapings obtained from lesions. The presence of eggs and mites of Sarcoptes scabiei var hominis is seen under the microscope and this confirms the diagnosis of scabies. However, the absence of eggs and mites under a microscope does not exclude the disease.

The Sarcoptes scabei mite is shown in the image below.

Treatment for scabies includes-

  • Antihistamines for pruritis
  • Application of topical 5% permethrin. It should be rinsed off after 8-12 hours. It can be reapplied after 1 week
  • Washing of clothes and linen and anti-scabetic treatment of family members.

Other options:

Option A: Pediculus corporis is caused by the body louse. Itching is the main complaint. The natural habitat of the louse is the clothing of its host, and it only visits the skin to feed. The skin may show excoriations, secondary bacterial infection, and hyperpigmentation. Eggs and lice will be seen in the clothing.

Option B: Cutaneous larva migrans is caused by hookworm infection and present as creeping erythematous lesions due to movement of the parasite in the skin. 

Option C: Tinea corporis is a fungal infection that presents with circular plaques with a sharp margin, raised edges, and itching. Common causative agents are T. rubrum and Microsporum canis.

questions.text:
Untreated syphilis passes through 4 stages from primary to late syphilis. Arrange the following features in the order of their occurrence.
  1. Positive serology with no clinical features
  2. Macular or papular syphilides
  3. Syphilitic gummata
  4. Chancre with bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 4,2,1,3.

Syphilis is caused by Treponema palladium. It is usually acquired through sexual contact and co-exists with other sexually transmitted diseases. However, congenital syphilis is acquired as a transplacental infection. The stages of untreated syphilis in the order of their occurrence are:
  • Primary syphilis presents as a papule on external genitalia that rapidly ulcerates to form a primary chancre. Inguinal lymphadenopathy usually accompanies the primary syphilitic lesion. The chancre in men is most commonly on the glans penis. They are primarily on the cervix and labia in women.
  • Secondary syphilis is the stage when generalized manifestations of syphilis appear on the skin and mucous membranes. A rash is commonly seen and this stage may be preceded by constitutional symptoms such as fever, sore throat, and malaise. The rash, known as syphilides is coppery-red, non-itchy, and symmetrical. It is initially macular, then progresses to papular syphilides.
  • Latent syphilis is the stage when there are no clinical features of the active disease but serological testing for the disease is positive.  
  • Late syphilis (tertiary syphilis) commonly presents as superficial or nodular punched out ulcers or gummas (granulomas appearing as cutaneous plaques or nodules with central ulceration) appears 3-10 years after infection. It may also present as red nodules (nodular syphilides), neurosyphilis, and cardiovascular syphilis. 
Serological testing is done using standard non-treponemal antibody tests like VDRL and rapid plasma reagin (RPR). Specific treponemal antibody tests like TPHA (T. pallidum hemagglutination assay) and FTA-ABS (fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test) are further required. 
Microscopically, Trepenoma palladium is identified with characteristic corkscrew morphology and motility on darkfield microscopy.
 
Parenteral penicillin G is the drug of choice for all stages of syphilis. If the patient has a history of drug allergies, it is advisable to keep the patient under observation for 15 to 20 mins after injection. An emergency kit for the management of anaphylaxis should always be available.
Treatment of recent sexual contacts is recommended. 
 

 

Related Pearl: Stages of syphilis

Primary syphilis:

  • Chancre - Painless, indurated, usually single. The chancre self heals in 1-4 months.
  • Lymphadenopathy - Painless, unilateral or bilateral, shotty and rubbery inguinal nodes
  • Dory flop sign - As the chancre is too hard to fold, it will flip over once the prepuce is retracted back.

Secondary syphilis:

  • A & B: Generalized non-itchy rash with no vesicles present on the palm and sole. This is the most common lesion.
  • C & D: Condyloma lata.
  • E: Moth-eaten non-scarring alopecia
  • F: Mucous patches are flat erosions on the tongue that can coalesce to form snail track ulcers. These are the most infectious lesions.
  • G: Pigmentary plaques
  • H: Psoriasiform syphilitic lesions
  • Generalized diffuse non-tender lymphadenopathy

Tertiary syphilis:

  • Gummatous syphilis are deep punched-out ulcers, with gum-like secretions on the floor
  • Pseudo-chancre redux is a gumma occurring at the site of a previously healed ulcer  
  • CVS - Aortitis and aneurysm of the ascending aorta
  • CNS - General paresis of the insane and tabes dorsalis 

Latent syphilis is the period between secondary and tertiary syphilis. In this period the patient is asymptomatic clinically and only serological evidence of the infection is present. It is classified into:

  • Early latent syphilis - Within 1 year of infection
  • Late latent syphilis - After 1 year of infection
